Situation1: They maintain daily communication with their parents, sharing detailed updates and responding promptly to messages.
Expectation2: Provide initial medical care to patients
Situation2: The ambulance driver is dispatched to a patient who has fallen and broken their arm, requiring basic pain management and stabilization.
Story: My phone buzzed in my pocket just as I pulled the ambulance to a stop outside the small brick house. I knew it was my stepdad—he always texted around this time, wanting to know how my day was going, expecting a quick reply and maybe a photo of my lunch. It was our routine, a way to keep close, especially since Mom passed. But as I stepped out, the dispatcher’s voice crackled in my earpiece: “Patient is conscious but in severe pain. Suspected fracture.” I grabbed the medical kit, my mind split in two. My stepdad’s message blinked insistently, but the woman on the porch was pale and clutching her arm, her face twisted in agony. I was supposed to be present for both—reassuring my family with words, and this stranger with care. My hands shook as I knelt beside her, feeling the weight of both worlds pressing in. I wanted to text back, to keep that fragile connection alive, but I couldn’t look away from the pain in front of me. The phone vibrated again, and I felt the familiar ache of letting someone down, no matter what I chose.
